page.title: 17GEOLOGY OF ULEY VALLEY
page.content: The area of the survey spans the Uley valley with evidence of tufa deposits and foothills of sandy rock.The north facing ecarpment of inferior and Great Oolitic Limestone rises up to the plateau of Symonds Hall Hill.This promontary which projects south west wards into the Severn Valley is divided by the Waterley Bottom Valley where are exposed the Sandy limestones of the Scisson bed which rest upon the Cephlapod Bed which 20ft thick and which contain fossils of ammanites and belemnites and many zone fossils.This is an area of Cottles Sand,fine yellow sand deposits up to 200ft thick.The Plateau is 600ft high, steep sided.The sides are cullivated where possible. Wooded on the steepest slopes,planted with conifers,many felled logging roads cut through follow contours. Grazing,hay and turnips.
